Unicode Version 13.0

Unicode 13.0 is the version of the Unicode Standard released on March 10, 2020. 55 new emoji code points were added in this release, with all 117 new emojis for 2020 (including sequences for gender and skin tone) listed under Emoji 13.0.

Unicode Version 12.0

Unicode 12.0 was released on March 5, 2019. Emojis that require new code points for release are listed on this page. See Emoji 12.0 for the full 2019 emoji list.

Example

ðŸ¥±

Unicode Version 11.0

Unicode 11.0 is the latest version of the Unicode Standard, released on June 5, 2018. Emojis that require new code points for release are listed on this page but for the full 2018 emoji list see Emoji 11.0.

Example

ðŸ¥°

Unicode Version 10.0

Unicode 10.0 is the version of the Unicode Standard released on June 20, 2017. 8,518 new characters were included with this update, of which 56 were emoji characters.

Example

ðŸ¤ª

Unicode Version 9.0

The Unicode Consortium accepted the following emoji 72 emojis for Unicode 9.0. This update was released on June 21, 2016. Most vendors added support for this update within the 2016 calendar year.

Example

ðŸ¤£

Unicode Version 8.0

The Unicode Consortium has approved the following 41 emoji characters as part of Unicode 8.0, released on June 17, 2015. This is comprised of 37 new emojis, plus five emoji modifiers.

Example

ðŸ™ƒ

Unicode Version 7.0

The Unicode Consortium has approved the following characters as part of Unicode 7.0, released on June 16, 2014. Support for these emoji characters rely on updates from platform vendors such as Apple, Google and Microsoft.

Example

ðŸ™‚

Unicode Version 6.1

A small update to the much larger Unicode 6.0. Unicode 6.1 included 13 new emoji characters.

Example

ðŸ˜€

Unicode Version 6.0

Released in October 2010, Unicode 6.0 was the first version of the Unicode Standard to support emoji.
